en.ForosSeccion: Connect, Share, Grow: Join Our Global Community of Farmers
en.Innovacion-descripcion:
Agriculture is undergoing a revolution driven by technology and sustainability. In this section, you will discover projects that apply artificial intelligence, smart sensors, precision irrigation systems, clean energy, and new agricultural practices designed to make crops more efficient and eco-friendly.

Each project we present aims not only to increase productivity but also to care for our soils, water, and the environment. Here you can explore modern solutions that are already changing the way we work the land and that could inspire the next big step in your own field.

Join us on this journey of innovation and sustainability, and see how technology and commitment to a better world come together in each of these projects.
en.Innovacion-riego-descripcion: Smart irrigation allows optimizing water use through sensors, timers, and data analysis. These systems detect soil moisture and weather conditions to supply only the necessary amount of water, reducing waste and improving crop yield.
en.innovacion-fertilizantes-descripcion: Ecological fertilizers, made from organic and natural materials, offer a sustainable alternative to chemical products. They contribute to soil health, promote healthy plant growth, and reduce environmental impact.
en.Innovacion-rotacion-descripcion: Crop rotation is an agricultural practice that involves changing the type of crop in a given plot over different seasons. This helps improve soil fertility, control pests and diseases, and prevent nutrient degradation.
en.Innovacion-vertical-descripcion: Vertical farming is based on cultivating in stacked structures or closed urban spaces, using technology such as LED lights and hydroponic systems. This technique allows maximizing space, reducing water use, and producing food closer to consumption centers.
en.Innovacion-Bioinsumos-descripcion: Bioinputs use living organisms, plant extracts, or minerals to control pests and diseases. They are a natural alternative to pesticides, helping to protect crops without harming the ecosystem or affecting human health.
en.Innovacion-Cultivos-descripcion: Thanks to biotechnology and genetic research, crops are being developed that can withstand extreme conditions such as droughts, high temperatures, or saline soils. This ensures a more stable production adapted to the effects of climate change.
en.innovacion-energia-descripcion: The use of solar panels on farms allows harnessing the sun's energy to power irrigation systems, machinery, or storage. This renewable source reduces energy costs and makes agricultural production more self-sufficient.
en.innovacion-sistemas-descripcion: These systems collect, filter, and store rainwater for later use in irrigation or cleaning. With sensors and automation, it can be managed efficiently, reducing dependence on traditional water sources.
en.Recursos-guia: Basic guide to optimize water use
en.Recursos-ahorrar: Discover how to save water in your crops by implementing simple practices such as watering early in the morning, using ground cover to retain moisture, and adjusting the amount of water according to the specific needs of each plant.
en.Recursos-aprende: Learn to plan your planting according to the seasons and climate. Know which crops thrive in spring, summer, fall, and winter to maximize your productivity throughout the year.
en.Recursos-manten: Keep your soil healthy and fertile with accessible methods such as crop rotation, using homemade organic fertilizer, and covering with plant residues to prevent erosion and retain nutrients.
en.Recursos-identificar: How to identify common pests and control them
en.Recursos-detecta: Detect the most common pests in your crops and learn to combat them naturally using repellent plants, beneficial insects, and other ecological solutions that protect your plants without harming the environment.
en.Recursos-reducir: Tips to reduce food waste after harvest
en.Recursos-evita: Avoid post-harvest losses with simple practices such as storing products in cool, dry places, using airtight containers, and planning distribution to ensure your food reaches the market fresh.
en.Recursos-optimiza: Optimize your space and improve the balance of your field by planting complementary plants together. For example, combine corn with beans or onions with carrots to take advantage of their mutual benefits and increase your production.
en.Historias-oportunidad: Sustainable agriculture is not only an environmental necessity but also an opportunity
en.Historias-oportunidad2: Andhra Pradesh, India Key Principle: Farming without external costs or chemical products
en.Historias-oportunidad3: The ZBNF project has revolutionized agriculture in India by training over 6 million farmers in natural techniques that eliminate the use of fertilizers and chemical pesticides. By implementing practices such as natural fermentation, crop rotation, and the use of green manures, farmers have reduced their operating costs by 80% and significantly improved soil quality.
en.Historias-oportunidad4: Additionally, a 30% increase in yields of crops such as rice and corn has been recorded.
en.Historias-oportunidad5: This model has not only strengthened food security but also decreased dependence on external loans, improving the economic stability of rural families.
en.Historias-CR1:
Location: Talamanca Region, Costa Rica
Key Principle: Integration of trees and crops
en.Historias-CR2: In the Talamanca region, small indigenous farmers have adopted agroforestry systems that combine crops like cocoa with native timber and fruit trees. This practice has restored degraded ecosystems, increased biodiversity, and improved the soil's ability to retain water. As a result, farmers have doubled their income by selling products certified as organic and sustainable in international markets. This approach has also contributed to climate change mitigation by capturing carbon.
en.Historias-EU: Regenerative Agriculture in the United States
en.Historias-EU1:
Location: North Dakota, USA
Key Principle: Soil recovery through regenerative practices
en.Historias-EU2: Gabe Brown, a farmer from North Dakota, has pioneered regenerative agriculture by implementing techniques such as permanent ground cover, diversified crop rotation, and controlled grazing. These practices have restored soil health, increasing its organic matter content by 500% in less than two decades.
en.Historias-EU3: Additionally, Gabe has managed to reduce operating costs by 75% and increase the profitability of his farm by diversifying his products and marketing them directly to local consumers. This case serves as a clear example of how agriculture can be both productive and environmentally friendly.
en.Historias-SG: Vertical Crops in Singapore: Innovation in Urban Spaces
en.Historias-SG1: In Singapore, a densely populated city-state, the lack of space has driven the adoption of vertical crops. Companies like Sky Greens have developed hydroponic and aeroponic systems that allow producing fresh food in small spaces using 90% less water than traditional agriculture. These advances have not only reduced dependence on food imports but also significantly decreased the carbon footprint associated with product transportation.
en.Historias-SG2: Additionally, the implementation of these technologies has generated jobs in specialized areas such as agricultural engineering and sustainable system management. This case demonstrates how innovation can solve urban challenges and ensure food security in resource-limited environments.
en.Historias-Cl: Sustainable Coffee in Colombia: Adapting to Climate Change
en.Historias-Cl1: In Colombia, small coffee producers have formed alliances with international organizations to implement sustainable agricultural practices through the Coffee and Climate program. This project has introduced techniques such as shading crops, using biodigesters to manage waste, and reforesting surrounding areas.
en.Historias-Cl2: As a result, there has been a 25% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and the certification of over 10,000 hectares under sustainable coffee standards. Additionally, producers have seen a significant improvement in the prices paid for their harvests due to organic certification. This example illustrates how collaboration between farmers, governments, and companies can generate effective climate solutions while strengthening the local economy.
en.Historias-BS: Agroecology in Brazil: The COOPFAM Cooperative
en.Historias-BS1: In Minas Gerais, Brazil, the COOPFAM cooperative has led the transition to agroecology by abandoning the use of chemical pesticides and adopting practices such as polyculture, the integration of livestock and agriculture, and comprehensive management of natural resources. These initiatives have increased local biodiversity by 60% and improved land resilience to droughts and floods.
en.Historias-BS2: Recognized internationally for its contribution to food security and environmental conservation, COOPFAM is a clear model of how agriculture can be both productive and respectful of the natural environment, promoting a balance between economic development and environmental protection.
en.Historias-CA: Reducing Food Waste: Full Harvest in California
en.Historias-CA1: In California, the company Full Harvest has created a digital marketplace that connects farmers with buyers interested in imperfect or surplus products. This innovative approach has reduced over 10 million pounds of food waste annually while providing additional income to participating farmers.
en.Historias-CA2: Additionally, it has raised consumer awareness about the importance of utilizing all food, regardless of its appearance. This case highlights how technology can be a powerful tool to promote sustainability in the food chain, benefiting both producers and the environment.
